how would you describe your main use cas: Note-taking;Journalling;Task and project management (including CRMs);As a knowledge base (including technical, non-fiction and encyclopaedic content)
do you share your tiddlywiki(s) with oth: No, but I may export content into other formats and share individual tiddlers, the whole wiki, or an extract of the wiki
putting it all together, what value does: It is my second brain or Zettelkasten containing my journals, daily activities, book notes, links, thoughts, status of personal projects, and other things I want to keep.
what is your level of ability with tiddl: I have customised TiddlyWiki through options and plugins;I am comfortable writing filter expressions;I have written custom JavaScript
how do you save changes in tiddlywiki?: Single-file wiki with custom saver (e.g. TiddlyPWA, Timimi, tw5-browser-nativesaver)
as you selected diy, would be grateful f: I use the Firefox timimi backup system on my desktop/laptop computers and the Quine 2 app backup system on my iPhone.

outside of plugins, palettes and other i: I've made many customizations from macros/functions/procedures to JavaScript modules. I package up most of my edits in a "personalnotebook" plugin for personal use that has all of my preferred configuration settings, templates, and functionality.
what are we doing well? prompts for thin: I think there is a great culture of keeping the core "dependency free" and "simple". These seem relative to me, so I'll explain how one outsider (non-TW developer) sees it. There is a good tendency to slow adding new features to ensure cruft doesn't build in the core, everything else is for plugins. Dependency-free because many JavaScript libraries could be added that would do many of the things--writing custom JavaScript for TW means only what is needed gets written. This in-turn drives simple.
what could we do better? prompts for thi: I'm excited for the next major version of TW. So much as changed since 5.x.x was started--JavaScript and browser technology has gone through several generations. Thus, the next major version is a chance to choose best practices as the way forward, deprecate and remove previous ways of doing things, and driving opinionated ways of customization to people who aren't in the weeds of the code regularly. It's great to have many ways of doing things, but also it can cause confusion and abandonment.
with your consent, we would like to publ: Yes, I am happy for my responses to be published
